item.title: Doctoral Research
item.description: For his Doctoral research, he investigated cognitive strategy use and individual differences during the mental rotation task with novel molecular model stimuli. For data analysis he employed model-based clustering on user response time distributions that classified people into two distinct strategy groups. Discriminant analysis and k-fold cross validation showed that the classifier had a predictive error of about 30%. One important finding was that a common spatial ability measure (cube comparison) predicted adherence to the slower error-prone mental rotation strategy, while abstract reasoning ability predicted use of a faster and more accurate non-rotation strategy.

item.title: Master's Research
item.description: His Master’s research involved engineering a tangible user interface and mirrored display apparatus that gave the haptic illusion of physically manipulating the virtual model.

item.title: Concrete and Virtual Models in Chemistry
